content: The "National Center for Transportation Solutions Act of 2004" establishes the National Center for Transportation Solutions and outlines its duties, organization, powers, and personnel matters. It also authorizes the creation of regional centers for transportation solutions and provides for the appointment of a Director of National Transportation Research. Congress finds that research and development in transportation are crucial for safety, mobility, economic vitality, efficiency, equity, and environmental protection. Despite a 40% increase in overall transportation funding, investment in transportation research and development has remained stagnant. Insufficient resources are allocated towards long-term transportation goals. Funding for transportation research and development has remained flat despite a 40% increase in overall transportation funding. Inadequate resources are devoted to long-term transportation goals, and the diversity of research programs poses challenges for effective priority setting. The competitive award of research funding is best suited for addressing strategic research needs to ensure the transportation system meets safety and mobility goals. The United States faces challenges in setting priorities for transportation research due to its wide-ranging subject matter. To meet safety, mobility, economic vitality, equity, and environmental protection goals, it is crucial to increase federal investment in long-range planning, support competitive research, coordinate Department of Transportation programs, facilitate data exchange, and establish nationwide research priorities. The Department of Transportation aims to foster data exchange and establish nationwide research priorities. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is established as an independent agency in the executive branch of government. It consists of the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board and the Director of National Transportation Research. The Board will exercise the authorities of the Center, with duties outlined in the Act. The National Center for Transportation Solutions will develop a long-term national policy for research and development in multimodal transportation. It will support projects with public benefits and provide grants to research institutions for strategic transportation objectives. The National Center for Transportation Solutions awards grants to research institutions for long-term transportation objectives and facilitates data interchange among interested parties in the US. The National Center for Transportation Solutions evaluates and coordinates transportation research programs, including those conducted by the US Government. The Director submits an annual report to Congress with recommendations on multimodal transportation research and development. The National Center for Transportation Solutions submits an annual report to Congress with recommendations on multimodal transportation research and development, including minority views and recommendations from board members. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established with 16 voting members, including appointments by the Secretary of Transportation, the Director of the National Academies, and the President in consultation with congressional leaders. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 members appointed by various government officials and leaders, representing different professions and regions of the United States. Initial appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, with members possessing skills relevant to the Center's functions. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 members appointed by various government officials and leaders, representing different professions and regions of the United States. Initial appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, with members serving staggered terms of 6, 4, or 2 years. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board has 16 members with staggered terms of 6, 4, or 2 years. Terms do not expire during election years, and initial terms can be extended for up to one year if needed. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board has 16 members with staggered terms of 6, 4, or 2 years. Terms do not expire during election years, and initial terms can be extended for up to one year if needed. Any vacancy in the Board does not affect its powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and meetings will be called by the Chair. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings, and a Chairman and Vice Chairman will be selected by the Board. The Board of the National Center for Transportation Solutions consists of 16 members with staggered terms. A majority of members form a quorum, and the Board selects a Chairman and Vice Chairman from its members for 2-year terms, with a limit of two consecutive terms for the Chairman. The Director of National Transportation Research, appointed by the President with Senate consent, serves as the chief executive officer of the Center, carries out its authorities, and is a nonvoting member of the Board. The Director serves a six-year term and receives a salary not exceeding the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Center is organized under the direction of the Director of National Transportation Research, who serves as the chief executive officer and is a nonvoting member of the Board. The Center is organized into divisions including Transportation Safety, Environmental Planning, Infrastructure, Intermodal Connections, and Transportation Economics. Each division has a committee composed of at least five members to advise the Board and Director. Each division committee, composed of at least five members, advises the Board and Director on relevant issues. Committee members serve two-year terms and elect a Chairman annually. Committees establish their own procedures within Board restrictions. The Center has powers outlined in Section 8. The Board and division committees have the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and enter into contracts to carry out the purposes of the Act. The Board and division committees have the authority to enter into contracts, use postal services, accept gifts, and publish research. SEC. 9. CENTER PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Director of the Center may appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. The staff is responsible for submitting strategic and annual plans, developing budgets, administering programs, and providing support to the Board. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. Responsibilities include developing budgets, administering programs, providing staff support to the Board, reporting progress to the Board, and coordinating with other organizations on transportation issues. Compensation for Center personnel can be determined by the Director independently. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. Compensation for Center personnel can be determined independently by the Director. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Center without reimbursement. The Director may procure temporary and intermittent services as needed. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. Compensation for Center personnel can be determined independently by the Director. The Director may procure temporary and intermittent services under specific regulations. Additionally, volunteer services can be accepted without certain restrictions. SEC. 10. REGIONAL CENTERS FOR TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS. The Director shall award grants to establish regional centers for transportation solutions in four regions of the United States. These centers will conduct research projects on regional multimodal transportation issues of long-term significance with clear public benefits. The northeast regional center will be located in a state meeting specific criteria. The northeast regional center established under this section will be located in a State with high levels of traffic congestion based on specific criteria related to National Highway System roads. Authorization of appropriations from the Highway Trust Fund for fiscal years 2006 to 2010: $50,000,000 in 2006, $100,000,000 in 2007, $150,000,000 in 2008, $200,000,000 in 2009, and $250,000,000 in 2010.
